attributes.description: Submission to Meta-Psychology. Contains the full history, including all correspondence, decisions, reviews, revisions etc.  Anyone can participate in open peer review directly by using the hypothes.is commenting function on the preprint.

attributes.title: Rural Electrification with Off-Grid Community Microgrids: An Impact Evaluation in Uttar Pradesh, India

q1.value: Rural Electrification with Off-Grid Community Microgrids: An Impact Evaluation in Uttar Pradesh, India

q2.value: Michaël Aklin | Patrick Bayer | S.P. Harish

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project is a randomized controlled trial on the economic, social, and political effects of solar microgrid deployment in rural Uttar Pradesh, India.

q17.value: "We conduct a randomized controlled trial. The treatment is access to a solar microgrid and is measured at the household level. Each microgrid provides enough electricity for charging or lighting. Microgrids are provided by our local partner, Mera Gao Power. The study begins with a baseline survey (pre-treatment) in a random set of households in February 2014 (about 1,600 respondents), and an endline survey (post-treatment) with the same households in early 2015. If we obtain additional funding, we may conduct a mid-line survey and/or additional surveys after 2015. "

If we obtain additional funding, we may conduct a mid-line survey and/or additional surveys after 2015. "

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan: The Broad Front: A Mass-Based Leftist Party in Latin America: History, Organization and Resilience

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan: The Broad Front: A Mass-Based Leftist Party in Latin America: History, Organization and Resilience

q2.value: Rafael Piñeiro | Verónica Pérez | Fernando Rosenblatt

q5.value: Fernando Rosenblatt is grateful to the FONDECYT #11150151 and also wishes to acknowledges support from the Chilean Millennium Science Initiative (project NS130008).‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Through an in-depth analysis of the Frente Amplio (FA, trans. “Broad Front,” Uruguay), this research studies the organizational attributes that support, and eventually limit, party leaders. It seeks to explain parties’ capacity to adapt, achieve consistent political performance, and, more generally, to persist over time. Organizational attributes operate as historical causes. The FA’s organizational attributes mediate the relationship between, on one hand, the party system’s logic of political competition and the incentives that favor some strategic decisions and, on the other hand, the way that parties adapt to social and economic changes and the politicization of new societal sectors and demands. This document presents a mixed-methods pre analysis plan. It registers our theoretical claims and the empirical strategy for a) the qualitative analysis that we will conduct in search of empirical referents to assess the descriptive inference of the FA as a mass-organic leftist party as well as the causal mechanisms of production and reproduction of this structure over time; and b) the experimental design that links the perception of activists´ effectiveness with their willingness to spend time and effort volunteering for the party.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (descriptive inference – origin): Since its formation , the FA has been a mass-organic leftist party (Levitsky and Roberts 2011 p. 13). To classify the FA as this type of party since its inception, one should observe the following attributes: 1) strong local branches; 2) active grassroots membership; 3) close ties to labor unions and other organized social constituencies; 4) labor intensive with widespread mobilization of grassroots partisan and social networks. Hypothesis 2 (causal inference - origin): The FA has been a mass party at its inception and during its first stage of development (1971-1986), because 1) the FA needed a mass organization to achieve significant electoral mobilization in the territory, and because of its need to articulate base activists from different sectors—organizations that antedate the FA—and independents; and 2) a popular movement, which preceding the FA and which was not organized by any of the sectors that created the FA, supported the creation of a mass-based party and claimed their place within this new organization. Hypothesis 3 (descriptive inference - reproduction): In the present, the FA is a mass organic leftist party (Levitsky and Roberts 2011). This means that the four attributes that define this type of party organization are observable at the FA at the time of our fieldwork. Hypothesis 4 (causal inference - reproduction): The FA did not oligarchize because of the political role granted to grassroots activists; they have always had representatives in the decision-making levels of the organization. This was granted to a level that ensured their ability to block changes in the organization´s statutes, engendering a lock-in effect. As a result (intermediate outcome), the FA combines organizers (base activists) and mobilizers (leaders from factions) within its structure (Han 2014). Hypothesis 5 (descriptive inference grassroots organization): The bases did not oligarchize. They still have an open democratic structure. Hypothesis 6 (causal inference of the non oligarchization of the bases): The bases do not oligarchize because they maintain a non-professional structure and they are not the first step in a political career to elective office; they are also not necessary to obtain a designated position in government. Hypothesis 7 (result, the FA in opposition and in government): The mass party organization restricts the decisions of the party elite while in opposition and in government: it limits the party leaders´ incentives to moderate. SURVEY EXPERIMENT: The reduction of the political role assigned to the bases negatively impacts the activists´ level of engagement. This hypothesis represents the causal relationship already discussed at the individual level. We are here surveying the relationship between an organizational attribute and individual behavior.

attributes.title: Identity-Safe Cues for Black Women at Tech Company 2 (Gender) x 2 (Race)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Identity-safe Cues for Black women at a Tech Company: Exploring whether among Black women, a White or Black male or female scientist signals identity-safe at a Tech Company

other.value:
We will look at correlations between all the primary outcome variables. If belonging, and trust and comfort are highly correlate, we may create a z-score composite to assess “anticipated trust and belonging” at the company. Moreover, if organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions are highly correlated, we also may create a z-score composite to examine “attraction” to the company. 
We also will run exploratory mediation analysis to examine whether there is an indirect effect of condition on identification via perceptions that the scientist had similar experiences with past adversity, and whether these is an indirect effect of condition on anticipated belonging at the company via identification.

sample.value: 400 Black female participants will be recruited for this experiment. This number was determined from an a priori analyses using G*Power and partial η-squared = 0.021 effect size (which determined we needed 368 participants). This effect size was taken from a previous experiment using a similar manipulation and outcome variables. We recruited a higher number of participants than we estimated requiring, to account for exclusion due to failed attention checks (described in the previous question) and excluding participants who don't identify as Black women.

analyses.value:
We will run between-subjects ANOVAs, to examine differences between conditions on the primary outcome measures. 
If we find that our manipulations influence perceptions about the percentage of Black/Female employees at the company, we will control for these perceptions in our ANOVA analyses, and will run follow-up ANCOVAs for our all of our outcome variables.

outliers.value: As mentioned above we will ask participants to briefly describe their impression of the scientist. We will exclude participants who put nonsensical answers for this question (e.g., “impressive” “very nice study” “prime survey ideas”).

dependent.value:
Black female participants will begin the experiment by being presented with a fictional technology company called “Comp Tech”. Participants will then be assigned to one of 4 company profile conditions. Specifically, participants will learn about a scientist working at the company who is either a Black or White man or woman.
Next, participants will complete a series of measures assessing their impressions of the scientist in the company profile. Specifically, participants will indicate a) the extent to which they believe the scientist has faced past bias, b) the extent to which they think the scientist has had similar experiences of adversity and similar experiences generally as themselves, c) their sense of self-other overlap and identification with the scientist, d) the extent to which they believe the scientist is an ally for women and Black individuals. 
Finally, participants will be given a short open-ended question to describe the scientist in the profile. We will code whether participants mention their scientist’s race and/or gender. That is, we will assess the extent to which the race/gender is salient for participants.
All participants will then be presented with the Comp Tech website a second time, and asked to imagine how they would feel being an employee at the company. Participants will then indicate their anticipated belonging, trust and comfort, organizational attraction, and job pursuit intentions for the company. We also will assess participants’ perceptions of procedural justice for Black employees and female employees at the company. Finally, we will measure the percentage of Black and female employees participants perceive work at the company. 
We will also have participants complete individual difference measures assessing the extent to which they believe women and Black individuals face bias in society and the centrality of their Black and gender identification.
As an exploratory measure, participants will have the opportunity read more about work related to scientist’s research on artificial intelligence. We will assess whether participants choose read about this work/research in computer science.

conditions.value: There will be four conditions –White man, White woman, Black man, and Black man scientists. 100 participants will be assigned to each condition.

hypothesis.value:
The primary goal of this experiment is to explore why Black women struggle to identify with a scientist who does not match their racial identity. Previous research has found that Black women identify more strongly and anticipant more belonging in a STEM environment with a Black male scientist compared to a White female scientist. That is a scientist with an overlapping racial identity is a more effective identity-safe cue than a scientist with only an overlapping gender identity. Although this phenomenon has been well established, what is less clear is why Black women identify more with a Black scientists than White female scientists. 
Previous work on intersectional identities has established that Black women are more sensitive to racism then sexism. Thus, we posited that Black women may be more likely to believe that a Black male scientist has had similar experiences with past bias/adversity than a White female scientist. These similar experiences should in turn relate to higher identification with the Black scientist, and identifying with a successful scientist will in turn encourage more interest and comfort in a STEM environment. 
Thus, we had the following predictions:
Black female participants will perceive a Black male and female scientist as having faced more similar experiences with adversity/bias than a White female and male scientist.
Black female participants will identify more strongly with a Black male and female scientist relative to a White female and male scientist.
Black female participants will anticipate more belonging in and be interested in working at a STEM company when they learn about a successful Black male or female scientist at the company compared to learning about a White female or male scientist.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

uploader.file_name: Capture attentionnelle et croyances, une étude de réplication.pdf

q1.value: Examining frequency effects for verbs belonging to the strong conjugation class in German with a lexical decision task

q3.value:
Frequency is a well-studied factor influencing variation (Bybee 1985, 2006, 2013, Nowak 2015). Type frequency influences variation in general: Inflection classes with low type frequency lose their members to type frequent classes. Type frequency also interacts with regularity. Mostly, classes with high type frequency show a regular conjugation pattern whereas classes with low type frequency show an irregular conjugation pattern (Goldberg 2019: 66-68).

Within the classes with low type frequency, token frequency influences whether a member will stay in the class or change to the type frequent class: token frequent members stay in the type infrequent class, while token infrequent members change to the type frequent class (Bybee and Thompson 1997). This principle has been studied in several corpus studies (e.g., Nowak 2015, Schäfer 2016). However, psycholinguistic studies on frequency and variation do not exist. 

In the past, psycholinguistic studies focussed on the difference between the processing of regular and irregular morphology and on the question whether token frequency only influences the processing of irregular conjugation, but not of regular conjugation (dual mechanism model by Pinker and Prince 1991; see Bornkessel-Schlesewsky 2009: 47-68 for an overview over the studies). Token frequency influences reaction times with regard to irregular verbs in general: Clahsen et al. (2001) report that preterite forms of irregular German verbs with a low frequency of preterite forms elicit slower reaction times in a lexical decision task than preterite forms of verbs with a high frequency of preterite forms. 
However, it has not been studied so far whether variation caused by low frequency might affect reaction times. It would be interesting to test whether the results of Clahsen et al. (2001) also hold for regular forms of irregular verbs with differing token frequencies. Additionally, it has not been examined whether variation can be detected in reaction times before it is visible in corpora. Here, irregular verbs are of interest that do not vary in corpora yet but have similar token frequencies as verbs that already show variation. Again, not only the reaction times elicited by irregular forms but also by regular forms of the verbs are of interest.

This study aims to answer the research questions with the help of a lexical decision task. For the task, verbs are used that belong to the type infrequent irregular (strong) conjugation class in German. The verbs have differing participle frequencies and show different degrees of variation in corpora. Participants are asked to judge the participle forms of the test verbs which are presented with strong (irregular) as well as weak (regular) inflection.

q4.value:
1. reaction times

frequent vs. infrequent

The reaction times depend on the frequency of the test verbs: Reaction times are lower for frequent strong verbs (over 13 hits per million tokens), whereas reaction times are higher for infrequent strong verbs (up to 2 hits per million tokens). This can be observed for weak as well as strong forms and for the acceptance as well as the rejection of forms. The relative frequency of the test verbs is determined with the help of the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften).

With the help of the design, reaction times can be interpreted as an indicator for variation. From a frequency-based view, reaction times should be shorter for frequent verbs than for infrequent verbs (Clahsen et al. 2001). The design allows to control for the general influence of frequency: Weak forms of token frequent verbs (e.g., "gezieht" instead of "gezogen" 'pulled') occur extremly seldom in language use and are thus not token frequent. A fast rejection of these forms can therefore not be traced back to the frequency of the forms. The same logic holds for weak forms of infrequent verbs ("gefechtet" instead of "gefochten" 'fenced') that are not attested in corpora yet (ratio of more than 100 strong forms to one weak form).  
Differences in reaction times can thus be interpreted as an indicator for variants:  entrenched forms are accepted fast and forms that are unlikely to be produced are rejected fast whereas the judgement of variants takes longer because two forms with equal function exist. Hence, the form "gezieht" should be rejected fast, but not "geflechtet": "geflechtet" is not attested in corpora yet, but the strong participle of "flechten" is similar frequent as the participles of other verbs that already show variation (e.g., "salzen" 'to salt'). Crucially, the hypothesised difference in reaction times cannot be traced back to differences in token frequency between the verb forms, as the token frequency of both forms ("geflechtet" and "gezieht") is equally low because both forms are nearly inexistent. 

attested vs. not attested

The infrequent verbs are divided into the categories variation attested in corpora and variation not attested in corpora. Based on a usage-based framework, it is hypothesised that no difference can be measured in the reaction times between forms that are attested in corpora and forms that are not attested in corpora. This holds for strong and weak forms as well as the acceptance and the rejection of forms. As the verbs are infrequent, the strong forms of the verbs are infrequent as well and thus cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency. Hence, the statistical pre-emption (Goldberg 2019: 75-84) of strong forms is impaired. Strong and weak forms can be considered variants for infrequent strong verbs. Reaction times are therefore higher as two forms with equal function exists. A prestudy supports this hypothesis (see https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_frequency.csv for the data and prestudy_frequency.R for the code analysing the data).
Note that it is also possible to expect differences in reaction time within a usage-based framework. As the weak forms are more seldom for verbs without attested variation and strong forms are in turn more frequent, a slight difference in reaction times might be observable between verbs with attested and verbs without attested variation. If weak forms occur only seldom, these forms should be rejected fast and the correspondent strong form should be accepted fast, as this is the only entrenched form. In contrast, longer reaction times are expected if weak forms occur more often as now there are two competing forms. However, this difference should be more subtle than the difference between frequent and infrequent test verbs because the strong forms of infrequent verbs cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency as much as strong forms of frequent verbs can.  
The design allows testing both hypotheses. The test verbs are selected by calculating the ratio of strong and weak participle forms using the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). The search was carried out with Cosmas 2 (Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). A form is defined to be attested in corpora if the ratio of strong to weak forms is smaller than 100/1. If no differences in reaction times can be measured between verbs with and without attested variation, this can be taken as an indicator that variation is already measurable before it is attested in corpora. 

2. acceptability and consistency of answers

frequent vs. infrequent

The acceptability of weak and strong forms depends on the token frequency of strong verbs. Strong forms are accepted for frequent strong verbs, whereas weak forms are not accepted. For infrequent strong verbs, both forms are accepted. 
For frequent verbs, a clearly distributed response behaviour is expected: predominantly rejection for weak forms and predominantly acceptance for strong forms. This is not expected for infrequent verbs: while acceptance is expected for strong forms, a mixed response behaviour is expected for weak forms. Additionally, the response behaviour of individual participants is expected to be consistent for frequent verbs (rejection of the weak form of a verb, acceptance of the strong form) but not for infrequent verbs (rejection/acceptance of both forms). 

variation attested in corpora vs. not attested in corpora

For infrequent test verbs, it is hypothesized that the acceptability of weak forms is influenced by the occurrence of weak forms in corpora. Although a corpus cannot picture language use as a whole, it can nonetheless give a hint on how likely it is that a certain form has been produced by speakers and hence perceived by other speakers. If weak forms are already attested in corpora, it is more likely that participants already encountered these forms and that the forms are more entrenchend. The opposite is to be expected for forms that are not attested in corpora. Weak forms are therefore more likely to be accepted if they already have been witnessed in corpora.  A prestudy supports this hypothesis (see https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_frequency.csv for the data and prestudy_frequency.R for the code analysing the data).
Note that this hypothesis is not the only possible hypothesis from a usage-based perspective. Comparable acceptance rates can also be expected: As the frequency of the strong participles is low for verbs with attested as well as without attested variation, the verbs could be treated in the same way. Hence, it is also possible that the infrequent verbs with and without attested variation show comparable acceptance and rejection rates of the weak and strong participle forms. The study design allows testing both hypotheses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
A within subject design is used with two factors (frequency and inflection), that have three (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of frequency, eight test words are used.  The participants are shown test words with weak as well as strong inflection and are asked to decide whether they know the word ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/word sequence?'). The answer (yes/no) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
So called weak masculine nouns with weak and strong inflection are used as fillers. They serve as test nouns for a study on the influence of schematicity on variation. Additionally,  strong genitive forms ending with -es are used as fillers. The genitive form -es is used for nouns that normally have -s as genitive ending as they do not allow -es phonotactically (*des Abendes 'the evening.GEN') (Szczepaniak 2010). 
To test the design, the reaction times elicited by long (-es) and short (-s) genitive endings of two nouns not allowing long genitive endings are contrasted (Ultimatum, Internet) as well as the reaction times elicited by regular and irregular forms of the irregular verbs "gehen" ('to go') and "bringen" ('to bring'). These items will only be relevant if the statistical analysis of the test items does not hint to differences in reaction times. The items allow to test whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The following mixed linear model will be used if the design needs to be tested: reaction time ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+acceptance |participant). Acceptance is the manipulated variable. The variable has two levels: accepted (short ending/irregular form) and not accepted (long ending/regular form). Additionally, the response behaviour (yes/no) of the participants will be analysed with the following logistic mixed linear model: response ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+form|participant). 

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study.

Test items
See the attached file (testverbs.csv) for an overview over the test verbs. The selection of the test verbs is based on the relative frequency of the test verbs' strong participles in the year 2018. The relative frequencies of the participles are taken from the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test verbs with a participle frequency of 13 and more hits per million token are considered frequent. Test verbs with a participle frequency of up to 2 hits per million token are considered infrequent. 

Within the infrequent test verbs, verbs with a ratio of more than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered not to vary in corpora, test verbs with a ratio of less than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered to vary in corpora. The counts for the strong and weak participle forms are based on the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). Only the hits for the weak forms of the frequent test verbs have been searched for false positives. Note that only hits with lower case for "gefahren" ('driven')  were included into the search in order to avoid false positives as "gefahren" in upper case is homographic to the dative plural of "Gefahr" ‘danger’.   

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over all test items as well as fillers. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: unique coding for each stimulus 	
Stimulus: the stimulus as presented to the participant	
Schema: coding for the masculine test nouns; levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach (not relevant for this study)
Frequenz: coding for the test verbs; levels: frequent, infrequ_m, infrequ_o
Akzeptanz: coding for the items testing the design; levels: nichtakzeptiert, akzeptiert	
Evaluation: "ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the items have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	
Flexion: coding for the test verbs and nouns; levels: stark/schwach	
Item: naming the test items in their base form (test verbs as well as masculine test nouns that are not relevant for this study)
Formakzeptiert: (expected) acceptence/inacceptance of the forms, j (yes), n (no), b (both)
correctKey: correct response key (based on Formakzeptiert); levels: f (no), j (yes, both)
Block: block in which the item is presented	
PositionimBlock: position within the block

Further explanation for the columns "Formakzeptiert" and "correctKey": Concerning the test verbs, the coding followed the hypotheses: for frequent verbs, weak forms are coded as rejected and strong forms as accepted. For infrequent verbs without attested variation (infrequ_o), the same coding scheme was used. For infrequent verbs with attested variation (infrequ_m), both forms were coded as accepted.

q9.value: The test items are organized in four blocks. Each block consists of 25 items. In the blocks, twelve test items (four test items per level) are included. Weak and strong forms of a single test verb are not used within one block but spread across blocks. Within the blocks, the order of the test verbs does not vary. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task. This evaluation will be based on 31 items. For these items, participants should not vary in their answers (the 31 items are fillers as well as words that are used in the example block and words that are used to evaluate the design of the study). The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer three items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants, whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category frequency (e.g., frequent/infrequent with variation) are excluded from the sample.
If the design has to be tested (see study design for further explanations), only the filler items as well as the items from the example block will be used to evaluate the participants' reponse behaviour. These are 23 items, hence, the cut-off point will be set to two or more items that have been answered in the opposite way in this case. 

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/decision.

q13.value:
A sample size of 50 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 100 participants will be recruited. In a prestudy, 13 of 32 participants (41 %)  had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category frequency (e.g., frequent/infrequent with variation). Hence, 50 % more data are collected in order to reach the targeted 50 participants.

See https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistration of the prestudy.  Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants were excluded whose reaction times were 3 sd higher than the mean of the reactions times for one of the levels of the category frequency (e.g., frequent/infrequent without variation).

q14.value:
The sample size is set to 50 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 50 particpiants are required to reach a power of over 0.9 with an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimates -0.14 for the level "frequent" of the category "frequency" and -0.22 for the level "strong" of the category "inflection" in comparison to the levels "infrequent without variation" and "weak". The estimates were calculated using a mixed linear model with the data of the prestudy. The data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_frequency.csv) as well as the code analysing the data statistically (prestudy_frequency.R) is attached. See https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_frequency.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy for 50 particpants is attached as well.The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_freq.csv).  See the section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).

question.value: Frequency was manipulated by choosing test verbs with differing participle frequencies. The three levels of this categorical variable are frequent, infrequent without variation and infrequent with variation (see study design for a definition of the levels). Additionally, the forms of the test words were manipulated. The levels of this nominal variable are weak and strong.

The outcome variables are response behaviour (yes/no) as well as reaction times to weak and strong participle forms of strong verbs with varying token frequencies (see manipulated variables). The response behaviour is measured by asking the participants 'Do you know this word/word sequence?' ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?"). Participants can only choose between yes and no. Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 


Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data will be used to exclude participants (see data collection procedures) but will not be used for the confirmatory analysis of the study.

For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019; RStudio team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction Times
To calculate the differences in reaction times, a mixed linear model is used. The frequency class of the verbs (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and the forms (strong, weak) will be included as fixed effects. Item and participant are included as random effects. For participants, random slopes and random intercepts are used. For items, only random intercepts are used as the items vary across categories. The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ frequency class + form + (1|item) + (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model. 

Acceptance
To evaluate the differences in acceptance (yes/no), a logistic mixed linear model is used. Forms (strong, weak) as well as frequency class (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) are included as fixed effects that may interact (rejection of weak inflection for a frequent verb but not for an infrequent verb). Item and participant are included as random effects. Again, random intercepts and random slopes are used for the participants, but only random intercepts for the items as they vary across categories. The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Acceptance is the dependent variable.

acceptance ~ frequency class * form + (1|item)+ (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

As the model for response behaviour indicated problems with multicollinearity in the prestudy (see prestudy_frequency.R); a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest was calculated additionally. This will also be used in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, frequency as well as inflection will be included as factors:

Key ~ Frequency + Inflection

For the tree, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_frequency.R.

q20.value: If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.

q21.value: The alpha level is set to .01. Based on the estimates for reaction times of the prestudy, an R2m of .12 and an R2c of .27  is expected.

q22.value: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants will be excluded that do not speak German as their L1, are bilingual or have dyslexia. Additionally, the response bevaviour of the participants will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation. In addition, participants whose reaction time is over 3 sd above the mean of reaction times for a level of the category frequency (e.g. frequent/infrequent with variation), will be excluded.

q23.value: Only complete data sets of participants will be included into the study. If meta data (except for  the indication of L1 and dyslexia) is missing, particpiants will still be included into the study.

q24.value: The prestudy indicated a possible interaction between frequency class and inflection. As the main interest of the study is not the interaction between the two factors, but the influence of differences in frequency, the interaction is not part of the confirmatiory analysis. However, a statisitical model including an interaction (RT~frequency*form+(1+frequency|participant)+(1|item)) will be calculated as part of the exploratory analysis. The same random effect structure will be used for this model as for the model of the confirmatory analysis.

q25.value:

Peirce, Jonathan; Gray, Jeremy R.; Simpson, Sol; MacAskill, Michael; Höchenberger, Richard; Sogo, Hiroyuki; Kastman, Erik; Lindeløv, Jonas Kristoffer (2019). PsychoPy2. Experiments in behavior made easy. In: Behavior Research Methods 51.1, 195–203.

Pinker, Steven; Prince, Alan (1991). Regular and Irregular Morphology and the Psychological Status of Rules of Grammar. In: Proceedings of the Seventeenth Annual Meeting of the Berkeley Linguistics Society: General Session and Parasession on The Grammar of Event Structure, 230–251.

registration_responses.q1: Examining frequency effects for verbs belonging to the strong conjugation class in German with a lexical decision task
registration_responses.q3:
Frequency is a well-studied factor influencing variation (Bybee 1985, 2006, 2013, Nowak 2015). Type frequency influences variation in general: Inflection classes with low type frequency lose their members to type frequent classes. Type frequency also interacts with regularity. Mostly, classes with high type frequency show a regular conjugation pattern whereas classes with low type frequency show an irregular conjugation pattern (Goldberg 2019: 66-68).

Within the classes with low type frequency, token frequency influences whether a member will stay in the class or change to the type frequent class: token frequent members stay in the type infrequent class, while token infrequent members change to the type frequent class (Bybee and Thompson 1997). This principle has been studied in several corpus studies (e.g., Nowak 2015, Schäfer 2016). However, psycholinguistic studies on frequency and variation do not exist. 

In the past, psycholinguistic studies focussed on the difference between the processing of regular and irregular morphology and on the question whether token frequency only influences the processing of irregular conjugation, but not of regular conjugation (dual mechanism model by Pinker and Prince 1991; see Bornkessel-Schlesewsky 2009: 47-68 for an overview over the studies). Token frequency influences reaction times with regard to irregular verbs in general: Clahsen et al. (2001) report that preterite forms of irregular German verbs with a low frequency of preterite forms elicit slower reaction times in a lexical decision task than preterite forms of verbs with a high frequency of preterite forms. 
However, it has not been studied so far whether variation caused by low frequency might affect reaction times. It would be interesting to test whether the results of Clahsen et al. (2001) also hold for regular forms of irregular verbs with differing token frequencies. Additionally, it has not been examined whether variation can be detected in reaction times before it is visible in corpora. Here, irregular verbs are of interest that do not vary in corpora yet but have similar token frequencies as verbs that already show variation. Again, not only the reaction times elicited by irregular forms but also by regular forms of the verbs are of interest.

This study aims to answer the research questions with the help of a lexical decision task. For the task, verbs are used that belong to the type infrequent irregular (strong) conjugation class in German. The verbs have differing participle frequencies and show different degrees of variation in corpora. Participants are asked to judge the participle forms of the test verbs which are presented with strong (irregular) as well as weak (regular) inflection.
registration_responses.q4:
1. reaction times

frequent vs. infrequent

The reaction times depend on the frequency of the test verbs: Reaction times are lower for frequent strong verbs (over 13 hits per million tokens), whereas reaction times are higher for infrequent strong verbs (up to 2 hits per million tokens). This can be observed for weak as well as strong forms and for the acceptance as well as the rejection of forms. The relative frequency of the test verbs is determined with the help of the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften).

With the help of the design, reaction times can be interpreted as an indicator for variation. From a frequency-based view, reaction times should be shorter for frequent verbs than for infrequent verbs (Clahsen et al. 2001). The design allows to control for the general influence of frequency: Weak forms of token frequent verbs (e.g., "gezieht" instead of "gezogen" 'pulled') occur extremly seldom in language use and are thus not token frequent. A fast rejection of these forms can therefore not be traced back to the frequency of the forms. The same logic holds for weak forms of infrequent verbs ("gefechtet" instead of "gefochten" 'fenced') that are not attested in corpora yet (ratio of more than 100 strong forms to one weak form).  
Differences in reaction times can thus be interpreted as an indicator for variants:  entrenched forms are accepted fast and forms that are unlikely to be produced are rejected fast whereas the judgement of variants takes longer because two forms with equal function exist. Hence, the form "gezieht" should be rejected fast, but not "geflechtet": "geflechtet" is not attested in corpora yet, but the strong participle of "flechten" is similar frequent as the participles of other verbs that already show variation (e.g., "salzen" 'to salt'). Crucially, the hypothesised difference in reaction times cannot be traced back to differences in token frequency between the verb forms, as the token frequency of both forms ("geflechtet" and "gezieht") is equally low because both forms are nearly inexistent. 

attested vs. not attested

The infrequent verbs are divided into the categories variation attested in corpora and variation not attested in corpora. Based on a usage-based framework, it is hypothesised that no difference can be measured in the reaction times between forms that are attested in corpora and forms that are not attested in corpora. This holds for strong and weak forms as well as the acceptance and the rejection of forms. As the verbs are infrequent, the strong forms of the verbs are infrequent as well and thus cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency. Hence, the statistical pre-emption (Goldberg 2019: 75-84) of strong forms is impaired. Strong and weak forms can be considered variants for infrequent strong verbs. Reaction times are therefore higher as two forms with equal function exists. A prestudy supports this hypothesis (see https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_frequency.csv for the data and prestudy_frequency.R for the code analysing the data).
Note that it is also possible to expect differences in reaction time within a usage-based framework. As the weak forms are more seldom for verbs without attested variation and strong forms are in turn more frequent, a slight difference in reaction times might be observable between verbs with attested and verbs without attested variation. If weak forms occur only seldom, these forms should be rejected fast and the correspondent strong form should be accepted fast, as this is the only entrenched form. In contrast, longer reaction times are expected if weak forms occur more often as now there are two competing forms. However, this difference should be more subtle than the difference between frequent and infrequent test verbs because the strong forms of infrequent verbs cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency as much as strong forms of frequent verbs can.  
The design allows testing both hypotheses. The test verbs are selected by calculating the ratio of strong and weak participle forms using the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). The search was carried out with Cosmas 2 (Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). A form is defined to be attested in corpora if the ratio of strong to weak forms is smaller than 100/1. If no differences in reaction times can be measured between verbs with and without attested variation, this can be taken as an indicator that variation is already measurable before it is attested in corpora. 

2. acceptability and consistency of answers

frequent vs. infrequent

The acceptability of weak and strong forms depends on the token frequency of strong verbs. Strong forms are accepted for frequent strong verbs, whereas weak forms are not accepted. For infrequent strong verbs, both forms are accepted. 
For frequent verbs, a clearly distributed response behaviour is expected: predominantly rejection for weak forms and predominantly acceptance for strong forms. This is not expected for infrequent verbs: while acceptance is expected for strong forms, a mixed response behaviour is expected for weak forms. Additionally, the response behaviour of individual participants is expected to be consistent for frequent verbs (rejection of the weak form of a verb, acceptance of the strong form) but not for infrequent verbs (rejection/acceptance of both forms). 

variation attested in corpora vs. not attested in corpora

For infrequent test verbs, it is hypothesized that the acceptability of weak forms is influenced by the occurrence of weak forms in corpora. Although a corpus cannot picture language use as a whole, it can nonetheless give a hint on how likely it is that a certain form has been produced by speakers and hence perceived by other speakers. If weak forms are already attested in corpora, it is more likely that participants already encountered these forms and that the forms are more entrenchend. The opposite is to be expected for forms that are not attested in corpora. Weak forms are therefore more likely to be accepted if they already have been witnessed in corpora.  A prestudy supports this hypothesis (see https://osf.io/ypw95 for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_frequency.csv for the data and prestudy_frequency.R for the code analysing the data).
Note that this hypothesis is not the only possible hypothesis from a usage-based perspective. Comparable acceptance rates can also be expected: As the frequency of the strong participles is low for verbs with attested as well as without attested variation, the verbs could be treated in the same way. Hence, it is also possible that the infrequent verbs with and without attested variation show comparable acceptance and rejection rates of the weak and strong participle forms. The study design allows testing both hypotheses.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

Weak and strong forms of a single test verb are not used within one block but spread across blocks. Within the blocks, the order of the test verbs does not vary. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

DeBruine, Lisa M.; Barr, Dale J.: Understanding mixed effects models through data simulation. PsyArXiv. https://psyarxiv.com/xp5cy/

Goldberg, Adele E. (2019). Explain Me This: Creativity, Competition, and the Partial Productivity of Constructions. Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press.

Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache. COSMAS I/II (Corpus Search, Management and Analysis System). http://www.ids-mannheim.de/cosmas2/

Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache. Das Deutsche Referenzkorpus DeReKo. http://www.ids-mannheim.de/kl/projekte/korpora/ 

Nowak, Jessica (2015). Zur Legitimation einer 8. Ablautreihe: eine kontrastive Analyse zu ihrer Ent-stehung im Deutschen, Niederländischen und Luxemburgischen. Hildesheim: Olms.

R Core Team (2019). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna. https://www.R-project.org/.

RStudio Team (2015). RStudio: Integrated Development for R. RStudio, Inc., Boston. http://www.rstudio.com/.

Szczepaniak, Renata (2010). Während des Flug(es)/Ausflug(es)? German Short and Long Genitiv Endings between Norm and Variation. In: Plewnia, Albrecht; Lenz, Alexandra N. (eds): Grammar between norm and variation. New York/Frankfurt am Main: Peter Lang, 103–126.

Peirce, Jonathan; Gray, Jeremy R.; Simpson, Sol; MacAskill, Michael; Höchenberger, Richard; Sogo, Hiroyuki; Kastman, Erik; Lindeløv, Jonas Kristoffer (2019). PsychoPy2. Experiments in behavior made easy. In: Behavior Research Methods 51.1, 195–203.

Pinker, Steven; Prince, Alan (1991). Regular and Irregular Morphology and the Psychological Status of Rules of Grammar. In: Proceedings of the Seventeenth Annual Meeting of the Berkeley Linguistics Society: General Session and Parasession on The Grammar of Event Structure, 230–251.

Schäfer, Roland (2016). Prototype-driven alternations: The case of German weak nouns. In: Corpus Linguistics and Linguistic Theory, 1–35.
registration_responses.q8.question:
A within subject design is used with two factors (frequency and inflection), that have three (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of frequency, eight test words are used.  The participants are shown test words with weak as well as strong inflection and are asked to decide whether they know the word ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/word sequence?'). The answer (yes/no) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
So called weak masculine nouns with weak and strong inflection are used as fillers. They serve as test nouns for a study on the influence of schematicity on variation. Additionally,  strong genitive forms ending with -es are used as fillers. The genitive form -es is used for nouns that normally have -s as genitive ending as they do not allow -es phonotactically (*des Abendes 'the evening.GEN') (Szczepaniak 2010). 
To test the design, the reaction times elicited by long (-es) and short (-s) genitive endings of two nouns not allowing long genitive endings are contrasted (Ultimatum, Internet) as well as the reaction times elicited by regular and irregular forms of the irregular verbs "gehen" ('to go') and "bringen" ('to bring'). These items will only be relevant if the statistical analysis of the test items does not hint to differences in reaction times. The items allow to test whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The following mixed linear model will be used if the design needs to be tested: reaction time ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+acceptance |participant). Acceptance is the manipulated variable. The variable has two levels: accepted (short ending/irregular form) and not accepted (long ending/regular form). Additionally, the response behaviour (yes/no) of the participants will be analysed with the following logistic mixed linear model: response ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+form|participant). 

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study.

Test items
See the attached file (testverbs.csv) for an overview over the test verbs. The selection of the test verbs is based on the relative frequency of the test verbs' strong participles in the year 2018. The relative frequencies of the participles are taken from the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test verbs with a participle frequency of 13 and more hits per million token are considered frequent. Test verbs with a participle frequency of up to 2 hits per million token are considered infrequent. 

Within the infrequent test verbs, verbs with a ratio of more than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered not to vary in corpora, test verbs with a ratio of less than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered to vary in corpora. The counts for the strong and weak participle forms are based on the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). Only the hits for the weak forms of the frequent test verbs have been searched for false positives. Note that only hits with lower case for "gefahren" ('driven')  were included into the search in order to avoid false positives as "gefahren" in upper case is homographic to the dative plural of "Gefahr" ‘danger’.   

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over all test items as well as fillers. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: unique coding for each stimulus 	
Stimulus: the stimulus as presented to the participant	
Schema: coding for the masculine test nouns; levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach (not relevant for this study)
Frequenz: coding for the test verbs; levels: frequent, infrequ_m, infrequ_o
Akzeptanz: coding for the items testing the design; levels: nichtakzeptiert, akzeptiert	
Evaluation: "ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the items have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	
Flexion: coding for the test verbs and nouns; levels: stark/schwach	
Item: naming the test items in their base form (test verbs as well as masculine test nouns that are not relevant for this study)
Formakzeptiert: (expected) acceptence/inacceptance of the forms, j (yes), n (no), b (both)
correctKey: correct response key (based on Formakzeptiert); levels: f (no), j (yes, both)
Block: block in which the item is presented	
PositionimBlock: position within the block

Further explanation for the columns "Formakzeptiert" and "correctKey": Concerning the test verbs, the coding followed the hypotheses: for frequent verbs, weak forms are coded as rejected and strong forms as accepted. For infrequent verbs without attested variation (infrequ_o), the same coding scheme was used. For infrequent verbs with attested variation (infrequ_m), both forms were coded as accepted.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task. This evaluation will be based on 31 items. For these items, participants should not vary in their answers (the 31 items are fillers as well as words that are used in the example block and words that are used to evaluate the design of the study). The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer three items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants, whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category frequency (e.g., frequent/infrequent with variation) are excluded from the sample.
If the design has to be tested (see study design for further explanations), only the filler items as well as the items from the example block will be used to evaluate the participants' reponse behaviour. These are 23 items, hence, the cut-off point will be set to two or more items that have been answered in the opposite way in this case. 

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/decision.
registration_responses.q16.question: Frequency was manipulated by choosing test verbs with differing participle frequencies. The three levels of this categorical variable are frequent, infrequent without variation and infrequent with variation (see study design for a definition of the levels). Additionally, the forms of the test words were manipulated. The levels of this nominal variable are weak and strong.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The outcome variables are response behaviour (yes/no) as well as reaction times to weak and strong participle forms of strong verbs with varying token frequencies (see manipulated variables). The response behaviour is measured by asking the participants 'Do you know this word/word sequence?' ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?"). Participants can only choose between yes and no. Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 


Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data will be used to exclude participants (see data collection procedures) but will not be used for the confirmatory analysis of the study.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019; RStudio team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction Times
To calculate the differences in reaction times, a mixed linear model is used. The frequency class of the verbs (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and the forms (strong, weak) will be included as fixed effects. Item and participant are included as random effects. For participants, random slopes and random intercepts are used. For items, only random intercepts are used as the items vary across categories. The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ frequency class + form + (1|item) + (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model. 

Acceptance
To evaluate the differences in acceptance (yes/no), a logistic mixed linear model is used. Forms (strong, weak) as well as frequency class (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) are included as fixed effects that may interact (rejection of weak inflection for a frequent verb but not for an infrequent verb). Item and participant are included as random effects. Again, random intercepts and random slopes are used for the participants, but only random intercepts for the items as they vary across categories. The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Acceptance is the dependent variable.

acceptance ~ frequency class * form + (1|item)+ (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

As the model for response behaviour indicated problems with multicollinearity in the prestudy (see prestudy_frequency.R); a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest was calculated additionally. This will also be used in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, frequency as well as inflection will be included as factors:

Key ~ Frequency + Inflection

For the tree, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_frequency.R.

attributes.title: The picture of venovenous ECMO treatment, outcomes, and complications according to large case series

summary.value:
Venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV ECMO) has gained popularity for the treatment of refractory respiratory failure during and after the 2009 influenza pandemic. However, most of the published studies are small case series and only two randomized trials exist in literature. This systematic review aimed to describe trends in VV ECMO treatment outcomes according to large studies only.
The information provided by this review is important for clinical practice, since in the era of the novel Coronavirus pandemic, the role of VV ECMO treatment is expected to be further strenghtened.

registration_responses.summary:
Venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV ECMO) has gained popularity for the treatment of refractory respiratory failure during and after the 2009 influenza pandemic. However, most of the published studies are small case series and only two randomized trials exist in literature. This systematic review aimed to describe trends in VV ECMO treatment outcomes according to large studies only.
The information provided by this review is important for clinical practice, since in the era of the novel Coronavirus pandemic, the role of VV ECMO treatment is expected to be further strenghtened.
